result.markdown:
# Pandas Basics Part 2 — Workbook In this lesson, we're going to introduce some more fundamentals of [Pandas](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/getting_started/overview.html), a powerful Python library for working with tabular data like CSV files. ___ ## The Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade Database "[D]isplaying data alone could not and did not offer the atonement descendants of slaves sought or capture the inhumanity of this archive’s formation." — Jessica Marie Johnson, “Markup Bodies” The dataset that we're going to be working with in this lesson is taken from [The Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade Database](https://www.slavevoyages.org/voyage/database), part of the [*Slave Voyages* project](https://www.slavevoyages.org/). The larger database includes information about 35,000 slave-trading voyages from 1514-1866. The dataset we're working with here was filtered to include the 20,000 voyages that landed in the Americas. The data was filtered to also include the percentage of enslaved men, women, and children on the voyages. ___ ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:46.821631Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:46.436585Z"}' execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd ``` ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:46.834660Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:46.828075Z"}' execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} data = [['Avatar', 'Neytiri', 2000, 2800], ['Avatar', 'Jake', 500, 2800], ['The Avengers', 'Loki', 700, 1518],['The Avengers', 'Thor', 800, 1518], ['My College Short Film', 'Myself', 100], ['My College Short Film', 'My Mom', 900]] df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns = ['Film', 'Character', 'Words Spoken','Box Office Gross (Millions)']) ``` ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:46.863065Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:46.850533Z"}' execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ```{=html}
Film Character Words Spoken Box Office Gross (Millions)
0 Avatar Neytiri 2000 2800.0
1 Avatar Jake 500 2800.0
2 The Avengers Loki 700 1518.0
3 The Avengers Thor 800 1518.0
4 My College Short Film Myself 100 NaN
5 My College Short Film My Mom 900 NaN
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:47.433960Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:47.409716Z"}' execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.groupby('Film').sum() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ```{=html}
Words Spoken Box Office Gross (Millions)
Film
Avatar 2500 5600.0
My College Short Film 1000 0.0
The Avengers 1500 3036.0
``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:47.659047Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:47.647768Z"}' execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.groupby('Film')['Words Spoken'].mean() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ``` Film Avatar 1250.0 My College Short Film 500.0 The Avengers 750.0 Name: Words Spoken, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:48.752077Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:48.732954Z"}' execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} df.groupby('Film').count() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ```{=html}
Character Words Spoken Box Office Gross (Millions)
Film
Avatar 2 2 2
My College Short Film 2 2 0
The Avengers 2 2 2
``` ::: ::: ## Import Pandas To use the Pandas library, we first need to `import` it. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:50.089412Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:50.083878Z"}' execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd ``` ::: ## Change Display Settings By default, Pandas will display 60 rows and 20 columns. I often change [Pandas' default display settings](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/options.html) to show more rows or columns. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:51.353374Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:51.347279Z"}' execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} pd.options.display.max_rows = 200 ``` ::: ## Get Data ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:52.539604Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:52.335130Z"}' execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df = pd.read_csv('../data/Trans-Atlantic-Slave-Trade_Americas.csv', delimiter=",", encoding='utf-8') ``` ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:53.938541Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:53.906635Z"}' execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=10} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: This creates a Pandas [DataFrame object](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/dsintro.html#DataFrame) — often abbreviated as *df*, e.g., *slave_voyages_df*. A DataFrame looks and acts a lot like a spreadsheet. But it has special powers and functions that we will discuss in the next few lessons. ## Overview To look at the first *n* rows in a DataFrame, we can use a method called `.head()`. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:55.823603Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:55.793603Z"}' execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.head(10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: Generate information about all the columns in the data ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:56.802859Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:56.758374Z"}' execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.info() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` RangeIndex: 20741 entries, 0 to 20740 Data columns (total 14 columns): # Column Non-Null Count Dtype --- ------ -------------- ----- 0 year_of_arrival 20741 non-null int64 1 flag 19583 non-null object 2 place_of_purchase 20663 non-null object 3 place_of_landing 20741 non-null object 4 percent_women 2894 non-null float64 5 percent_children 2927 non-null float64 6 percent_men 2894 non-null float64 7 total_embarked 20722 non-null float64 8 total_disembarked 20719 non-null float64 9 resistance_label 372 non-null object 10 vessel_name 20741 non-null object 11 captain's_name 19396 non-null object 12 voyage_id 20741 non-null int64 13 sources 20741 non-null object dtypes: float64(5), int64(2), object(7) memory usage: 2.2+ MB ``` ::: ::: Just like Python has different data types, Pandas has different data types, too. These data types are automatically assigned to columns when we read in a CSV file. We can check these Pandas data types with the [`.dtypes` method](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.dtypes.html). | **Pandas Data Type** | **Explanation** | |:-------------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------:| | `object` | string | | `float64` | float | | `int64` | integer | | `datetime64` | date time Make a histogram of the DataFrame ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:59.738667Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:58.483303Z"}' execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.hist() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ``` array([[, , ], [, , ], [, , ]], dtype=object) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04.5-Pandas-Basics-Part2-WORKBOOK_files/figure-html/cell-15-output-2.png){} ::: ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:00.411918Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:19:59.754604Z"}' execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.hist(figsize=(10,10)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ``` array([[, , ], [, , ], [, , ]], dtype=object) ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04.5-Pandas-Basics-Part2-WORKBOOK_files/figure-html/cell-16-output-2.png){} ::: ::: Generate descriptive statistics for all the columns in the data ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:00.452794Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:00.427915Z"}' execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.describe() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Missing Data "Black digital practice requires researchers to witness and remark on the marked and unmarked bodies, the ones that defy computation, and **finds ways to hold the null vlaues up to the light.**" —Jessica Marie Johnson ### .isna() / .notna() Pandas has special ways of dealing with missing data. As you may have already noticed, blank rows in a CSV file show up as `NaN` in a Pandas DataFrame. To filter and count the number of missing/not missing values in a dataset, we can use the special `.isna()` and `.notna()` methods on a DataFrame or Series object. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:02.597404Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:02.585390Z"}' execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df['percent_women'].notna() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=17} ``` 0 False 1 False 2 False 3 False 4 False ... 20736 False 20737 False 20738 False 20739 False 20740 False Name: percent_women, Length: 20741, dtype: bool ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:02.987801Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:02.983003Z"}' execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} not_blank_women = slave_voyages_df['percent_women'].notna() ``` ::: To explicitly count the number of blank rows, we can use the `.value_counts()` method. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:03.773502Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:03.756663Z"}' execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df['percent_women'].isna().value_counts() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=19} ``` True 17847 False 2894 Name: percent_women, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: To quickly transform these numbers into percentages, we can set the `normalize=` parameter to True. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:22.005927Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:21.993442Z"}' execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df['percent_women'].isna().value_counts(normalize=True) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=20} ``` True 0.86047 False 0.13953 Name: percent_women, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: Because the `.count()` method always excludes NaN values, we can also count the number of values in each column and divide by the total number of rows in each column (`len()`) to find the percentage of not blank data in every column. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:22.373988Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:22.330879Z"}' execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.count() / len(slave_voyages_df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=21} ``` year_of_arrival 1.000000 flag 0.944169 place_of_purchase 0.996239 place_of_landing 1.000000 percent_women 0.139530 percent_children 0.141121 percent_men 0.139530 total_embarked 0.999084 total_disembarked 0.998939 resistance_label 0.017935 vessel_name 1.000000 captain's_name 0.935153 voyage_id 1.000000 sources 1.000000 dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ## Sort Columns We can sort a DataFrame with the `.sort_values()` method, inside of which we include the parameter `by=` and indicate the name of the column we want to sort by (written in quotation marks). ### ❓ Which voyages had the highest percentage of women on board? ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:09.892105Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:09.888820Z"}' tags='["output_scroll"]' execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} # slave_voyages_df... ``` ::: ## Calculate Columns We can do different calculations on columns with built-in Pandas functions. These calculations will ignore `NaN` values. | Pandas calculations | Explanation | |----------|-------------------------------------| | `.count()` | Number of observations | | `.sum()` | Sum of values | | `.mean()` | Mean of values | | `.median()` | Median of values | | `.min()` | Minimum | | `.max()` | Maximum | | `.mode()` | Mode | | `.std()` | Unbiased standard deviation | ### ❓ What was the average percentage of women aboard the voyages? ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:11.478696Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:11.448036Z"}' execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=23} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Rename Columns We can rename columns with the [`.rename()` method](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.rename.html) and the `columns=` parameter. For example, we can rename the "flag" column "national_affiliation." ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:14.005594Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:13.976483Z"}' execution_count=28} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.rename(columns={'flag': 'national_affiliation'}) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=27} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Groupby Columns The Pandas function`.groupby()` allows us to group data and perform calculations on the groups. For example, Jennifer Morgan writes about how some nations recorded more information about the gender of the enslaved people aboard their voyages than other nations did. To see the breakdown of gender information by nation, we can use a `.groupby()` function. ### ❓ Which nation recorded the most information about gender? To answer this question, you can use the `.groupby()` method and the `.count()` method, which will show you the number of non-blank values in each column. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:16.674394Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T11:20:16.668370Z"}' execution_count=32} ``` {.python .cell-code} # slave_voyages_df... ``` ::: "For example, patterns emerge that suggest that English slave ship captains provided the most data related to the age or sex characteristics of the captives they transported and sold into slavery...The degree to which the practice of recording the sex of the passengers on board accords to national origin raises some interesting questions about the possible correlations between certain notational and national presumptions of accountability." -Jennifer Morgan, ["Accounting for 'The Most Excruciating Torment'"](https://read.dukeupress.edu/history-of-the-present/article-abstract/6/2/184/153282/Accounting-for-The-Most-Excruciating-Torment?redirectedFrom=PDF) ## Add Columns To add a column, we simply put a new column name in square brackets and set it equal to whatever we want the new column to be. For example, if we wanted to create new columns for the total women and men aboard each voyage, we could set them equal to the product of the "total_disembarked" column * the "percent_women" / "percent_men" columns. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:42.193556Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:42.185829Z"}' execution_count=33} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df['total_women'] = slave_voyages_df['total_embarked'] * slave_voyages_df['percent_women'] ``` ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:42.639933Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:42.633886Z"}' execution_count=34} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df['total_men'] = slave_voyages_df['total_embarked'] * slave_voyages_df['percent_men'] ``` ::: If we scroll all the way to the right side of the DataFrame, we can see that these columns have been added. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:43.438658Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:43.413605Z"}' execution_count=35} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.head(1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=34} ```{=html}
year_of_arrival national_affiliation place_of_purchase place_of_landing percent_women percent_children percent_men total_embarked total_disembarked resistance_label vessel_name captain's_name voyage_id sources total_women total_men
0 1520 NaN Portuguese Guinea San Juan NaN NaN NaN 324.0 259.0 NaN NaN 42987 [u'AGI,Patronato 175, r.9<><p><em>AG!</em> (Se... NaN NaN
``` ::: ::: ## Plots and Data Visualizations ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:44.199156Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:44.183737Z"}' execution_count=36} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.groupby('national_affiliation')['percent_women'].count() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=35} ``` national_affiliation Denmark / Baltic 119 France 708 Great Britain 1123 Netherlands 200 Other 0 Portugal / Brazil 42 Spain / Uruguay 468 U.S.A. 223 Name: percent_women, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:44.375253Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:44.369354Z"}' execution_count=37} ``` {.python .cell-code} nation_by_gender = slave_voyages_df.groupby('national_affiliation')['percent_women'].count() ``` ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:44.931779Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:44.801522Z"}' execution_count=38} ``` {.python .cell-code} nation_by_gender.plot(kind='bar', title='Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade (Americas): \n Slave Voyages with Recorded Gender Information') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=37} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04.5-Pandas-Basics-Part2-WORKBOOK_files/figure-html/cell-39-output-2.png){} ::: ::: To make a time series, we would typically want to convert our date column into datetime values rather than integers. Since we're only working with year information, however, we can make some simple time series plots just by grouping by the year column and performing calculations on those year groupings. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:45.593543Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:45.577862Z"}' execution_count=39} ``` {.python .cell-code} slave_voyages_df.groupby('year_of_arrival')['total_women'].sum() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=38} ``` year_of_arrival 1520 0.0 1525 0.0 1526 0.0 1527 0.0 1532 0.0 ... 1862 0.0 1863 0.0 1864 0.0 1865 0.0 1866 0.0 Name: total_women, Length: 330, dtype: float64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:45.735138Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:45.731037Z"}' execution_count=40} ``` {.python .cell-code} total_women_by_year = slave_voyages_df.groupby('year_of_arrival')['total_women'].sum() ``` ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:46.323870Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:46.209558Z"}' execution_count=41} ``` {.python .cell-code} total_women_by_year.plot() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=40} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04.5-Pandas-Basics-Part2-WORKBOOK_files/figure-html/cell-42-output-2.png){} ::: ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:46.514606Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:46.397011Z"}' execution_count=42} ``` {.python .cell-code} total_women_by_year.plot(kind='line', title="Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade (Americas):\nTotal Number of Enslaved Women on Voyages") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=41} ``` ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](04.5-Pandas-Basics-Part2-WORKBOOK_files/figure-html/cell-43-output-2.png){} ::: ::: We can plot multiple columns at the same time by using two square brackets. For example, we can compare the total number of women and men aboard the voyages. ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:47.030171Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:47.021691Z"}' execution_count=43} ``` {.python .cell-code} total_men_by_year = slave_voyages_df.groupby('year_of_arrival')['total_men'].sum() ``` ::: ::: {.cell ExecuteTime='{"end_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:47.556593Z","start_time":"2022-11-07T10:51:47.405111Z"}' execution_count=44} ``` {.python .cell-code} total_women_by_year.plot(kind='line', legend= True, title="Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade (Americas):\nTotal Number of Enslaved Women on Voyages") total_men_by_year.plot(legend=True) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=43} ``` ```
